Hi, Mick (and/or others, of course),

I'm loath to ask this, given the stupendosity (-iciousness?) of this build, but I'm in the midst of trying to convert someone to NwN. We've agreed to join a PW with 2 characters I'm currently test-driving through Aielund, but he wants to try a run-through in SP first. He doesn't want to do the OC or SoU/HotU (it was he who first gave me the discs, having got fed up in Chapter 1 of the OC and never returned to it), so I figured Aielund would be a good idea. He's even more of a non-caster than I am (trying to change that currently), as well as a meleer moving from BG and IWD, and he's not a fan of the radial system. Thus, this looks to be the ideal build for him, except...

Aielund's a non-Dev Crit environment, and stops at level 36. So, what would you recommend?  Losing OW and Dev Crits don't seem too hard, given that I'll be losing a Feat and a Bonus Feat anyway, and I'll be losing 5 Tumbles (pushing Monk 3 up to L32) whether I bring Monk 4 into pre-L36 or not. But would you replace some of the Fighter levels with the lost CoT ones in epic or not? My maths (sorry, British) is letting me down. I would guess yes, but thought I'd ask. Pre-epic, I can bin Great Cleave with no problem and whack Imp Crit: Heavy Flail in its place, which is grand.

I don't like messing with quality, but I want him to enjoy as much as possible - else he'll go back to Morrowind. I'm trying to grow some support here

Cheers

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
I'll post my gut impressions just to see what Mick's take is and to compare.

You can do 4 monk levels pre-epic without affecting the BAB (29) if you like.  You'll lose at least 1 feat that way and wave bye-bye to Great Cleave. Then in epic, try to make it to Monk 12 to get the only thing missing from the build... SR.  And there's simply nothing better than monk SR, right?  Just an idea that popped out of the air.

But, with all that said... I think you should stick with the double weapon specialization.  Reason:  Besides the alternate damage type being VERY handy, your disarm attempts won't be nearly as successful with the scimi so all attempts should be made with the large weapon.  But the s/s switch is also important if the AC isn't cutting it without a shield.  The only combat feat missing that I generally use in my fighters are called arm shots which can effectively increase your AC significantly and stacks with itself.  But called shots are not modal so require some management that your friend may not care to engage in, regardless of its effectiveness.  Sort of like a monk using stunning fists, also not modal.

BTW, your friend has good instincts.  Why waste an opportunity to learn party tactics on the silly-easy OC?  That won't help on-line play anywhere. 

Aielund is really not all that hard either, but the story should help to keep him interested.  You didn't specify what sort of PW, Stagmeister. 

If it's a server heavy on RP, Aielund is a very good training ground.  But if it's more geared towards action with quickly-respawning encounters, a more combat-oriented campaign would be better, something like HotU but more challenging.  Typically, those sorts have little plot immersion.  Don't ask me to recommend any combat-heavy modules because the last one I played was Infinite Dungeons and after that I began building epic trainers myself.  But I am sure they are out there, languishing in the Vault somewhere, because encounters are the easiest features to script.

posts.author: HipRedux

Empyre65 wrote:
To be honest, I don't understand the benefit of Monk in this build. There must be a benefit because people keep doing this. Evasion?

 
It's Mick's build so I can only make conjecture, but in this case...

Trying to specialize in two weapons simultaneously is no easy feat (no pun intended).  He chose a tumble class that coincidentally furnished one of the prereq feats for DevCrit.  Certainly the Evasion doesn't hurt vs. reflex either.  Also, in a saves-conscious build, the best class is monk, the only tumble class with all high saves.  My suggestion to Stagmeister, though, about increasing the number of monk levels, creates somewhat of a conundrum because both KD and IKD are allocated feats during pre-epic.  A Ftr6/CoT6/Mnk8 pre-epic split would reduce the BAB by 1 and play hell with procuring both weapon specialities, one of which was destined to achieve DevCrit status.  So dunno if that split is such a good idea.
Diasrm is not as useful in PvM as it is in PvP because most monsters don't have weapons to disarm.
 
True.  Either is Disarm ("Diasrm" sounds like some sort of intestinal disorder being used offensively somehow.). *lol*  But in the case of an encounter with drow assassins or other such sneaky creatures, eliminating their poisoned swords or daggers pretty much limits them to unarmed attacks and being opened up to AoOs. Some times a creature will have intrinsic feats attached to their weapon, like +AC, ability/skill boosts or even Permahaste.  If one hit can disable those advantages, it well worth the investment.  IMO, if one is planning disarm attempts, either use a large weapon with ImpDisarm or just stick to KD/IKD or Called Shots to level the playing field.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Sorry, it was one of my own MUAs (Made Up Acronyms) - so about as far from being hipster slang as you can get.

I meant to include this earlier, but got distracted. In case you're interested, my final adaptations for Billy were:

Pre-epic. Kept all the class splits as is. Pushed Expertise back to L3 and took Weapon Prof: Exotic in at L1 (gives even more freedom of weaponry, and you'll never hit anything with Expertise on for the first level or 2). This meant taking Knockdown at L6. I put Imp Crit: Heavy Flail in at L12 and dropped Imp Knockdown down to L15, with Blind Fighting sneaking in at L14. From this, you will gather that I dropped both the Disarm feats (following earlier contributions on this thread) - I went for Called Shot instead, which resides at L19 in place of Great Cleave. Hope that sounds reasonable.

Epic. (Please remember that these tweaks were for a level 36 build). Made L22 EWF: Heavy Flail, then L24 EWS: Scimitar and L26 EWS: Heavy Flail. Epic Prowess went in at L29, and Armour Skin at L31. I then swapped a CoT level for one of Monk at L32, so I'd only lose 5 points of Tumble by L36. This meant that CoT 14 now comes in at L36, and I must confess that I'm at a bit of a loss as to what to take as the Bonus Feat there. Any thoughts would be welcome. I wondered about Epic Energy Resistance or Epic Skill Focus in either Discipline or Spellcraft, but I remain a little unclear as to whether I could take either without their baby versions (or indeed at all, for EER), and whether ESkF in Spellcraft would make a blind bit of difference.

Hope I haven't wrecked your build, Mick.

Thanks a lot, y'all

Your saves are more than fine. Discipline, likewise. 

Maybe ESkF: Spot if you are still using MIck's suggested allocation.  Mechanically, I'd have preferred Listen + ESkF but you'd be needing to wait for those sparse monks dumps and at least the Spot increases each level to help detection throughout the build.  Don't forget to use those Owl pots for pre-buff before venturing if the environment makes them available.  Wouldn't hurt your Will saves either.

Epic skill focus requires 20 ranks in the chosen skill.  Nothing more involved than being an epic character.  EER, just epic levels.
